image

ImageBase

class sis.image.ImageBase

Bases: object

Base class representing a 4D image (frames, rows, columns, channels)

Defines basic methods for navigating and displaying the underlying data, but does not define how it should be read in or stored.

property shape

Return 4D shape (frames, rows, columns, channels)

get_channel(channel: str)

Return a view of this image limited to the given channel (e.g.: ‘DAPI’ or ‘PolyT’)

Parameters:

channel (str) – Name of channel to return data from

Returns:

A view of this image limited to the channel

Return type:

ImageView

get_subregion(region: tuple | list[tuple] | list[list], incl_end=False)

Return a view of this image limited to the spot coordinate-defined region ((xmin, xmax), (ymin, ymax))

Parameters:

  • region (tuple or list[tuple] or list[list]) – Region to return data from

  • incl_end (bool) – Include all pixels of the image that overlap with the region, rather than just those inside the region.

Returns:

A view of this image limited to the region

Return type:

ImageView

bounds()

Return (xlim, ylim) bounds of the image in spot coordinates

Return type:

tuple

get_frame(frame: int | None)

Return a view of this image limited to the given frame

Parameters:

frame (int or None) – Frame to return data from

Return type:

ImageView

get_frames(frames: tuple | int | None)

Return a view of this image limited to the given frames

Parameters:

frames (tuple or int or None) – if tuple: first_frame is inclusive, last_frame is exclusive if int: single frame to return if None: return full image

Return type:

ImageView

show(ax=None, frame: int | str | None = None, channel: str | None = None, **kwds)

Show the image in a matplotlib axis

Parameters:

  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes or None, optional) – Axis to show image in

  • frame (int or str or None, optional) – Single frame to show. Can be ‘mean’ to show the mean of all frames

  • channel (str or None, optional) – Channel to show

  • **kwds (dict[str, Any]) – Additional keyword arguments to pass to imshow()

Image

class sis.image.Image(data: ndarray, transform: ImageTransform, channels: list, name: str | None = None)

Bases: ImageBase

An Image defined by 4D numpy array (frames, rows, cols, channels).

Carries metadata about pixel transform and channel identity.

transform

Transformation mapping from pixel coordinates to spot coordinates

Type:

ImageTransform

channels

List of names given to each channel (e.g.: ‘dapi’)

Type:

list

name

Optional unique identifier for this image

Type:

str or None

_data

4D array of image data

Type:

np.ndarray

__init__(data: ndarray, transform: ImageTransform, channels: list, name: str | None = None)
property shape

Return 4D shape (frames, rows, columns, channels)

Return type:

tuple

get_data(channel=None)

Return array of image data.

If the image has multiple channels, then the name of the channel to return must be given.

Parameters:

channel (str or None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

get_sub_data(frames: tuple, rows: tuple, cols: tuple, channel: str | None = None)

Get image data for a subregion (defined by frames, rows, and cols, NOT by spot coordinates)

Parameters:

  • frames (tuple) – first frame is inclusive, last_frame is exclusive

  • rows (tuple) – first row is inclusive, last_row is exclusive

  • cols (tuple) – first col is inclusive, last_col is exclusive

  • channel (str or None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

ImageFile

class sis.image.ImageFile

Bases: ImageBase

Base class for accessing image files on disk.

property shape

Return 4D shape (frames, rows, columns, channels)

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_data(channel=None)

Return array of image data. If the image has multiple channels, then the name of the channel to return must be given.

Parameters:

channel (str|None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_sub_data(frames: tuple, rows: tuple, cols: tuple, channel: str | None = None)

Return a subset of the ImageData

Parameters:

  • frames (tuple) – first frame is inclusive, last_frame is exclusive

  • rows (tuple) – first row is inclusive, last_row is exclusive

  • cols (tuple) – first col is inclusive, last_col is exclusive

  • channel (str or None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

Returns:

Subregion of image data

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

MerscopeImageFile

class sis.image.MerscopeImageFile(file: str, transform: ImageTransform, axes: list | None, channels: list, name: str | None)

Bases: ImageFile

Represents a single image stored on disk, carrying metadata about:

  • The file containing image data

  • The transform that maps from pixel coordinates to spot table coordinates

  • Which axes are which

  • What is represented by each channel

Image data are lazy-loaded so that we can handle subregions without loading the entire image

file

Path to image file

Type:

str

transform

ImageTransform relating (row, col) image pixel coordinates to (x, y) spot coordinates.

Type:

ndarray

axes

List of axis names giving order of axes in file; options are ‘frame’, ‘row’, ‘col’, ‘channel’

Type:

list

channels

List of names given to each channel (e.g.: ‘dapi’)

Type:

list

name

Optional unique identifier for this image

Type:

str or None

_shape

Cached shape of the image, to avoid reading it from disk multiple times

Type:

tuple or None

__init__(file: str, transform: ImageTransform, axes: list | None, channels: list, name: str | None)
Parameters:

  • file (str) – Path to image file

  • transform (ndarray) – ImageTransform relating (row, col) image pixel coordinates to (x, y) spot coordinates.

  • axes (list) – List of axis names giving order of axes in file; options are ‘frame’, ‘row’, ‘col’, ‘channel’

  • channels (list) – List of names given to each channel (e.g.: ‘dapi’)

  • name (str or None) – Optional unique identifier for this image

classmethod load(image_file, transform_file, channel, name=None)

Read a Merscope image file and return an ImageFile object

Parameters:

  • image_file (str) – Path to image file

  • transform_file (str) – Path to transform file

  • channel (str) – Name of channel which this image represents

  • name (str or None, optional) – Optional unique identifier for this image

Return type:

MerscopeImageFile

get_sub_data(frames: tuple, rows: tuple, cols: tuple, channel: str | None = None)

Get image data for a subregion (defined by frames, rows, and cols, NOT by spot coordinates)

Parameters:

  • frames (None) – not used for merscope image files since they are split by frame already, but left for compatibility

  • rows (tuple) – first row is inclusive, last_row is exclusive

  • cols (tuple) – first col is inclusive, last_col is exclusive

  • channel (str or None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

StereoSeqImageFile

class sis.image.StereoSeqImageFile(file: str, transform: ImageTransform, axes: list | None, channels: list, name: str | None)

Bases: ImageFile

Represents a single image stored on disk, carrying metadata about:

  • The file containing image data

  • The transform that maps from pixel coordinates to spot table coordinates

  • Which axes are which

  • What is represented by each channel

Image data are lazy-loaded so that we can handle subregions without loading the entire image

file

Path to image file

Type:

str

transform

ImageTransform relating (row, col) image pixel coordinates to (x, y) spot coordinates.

Type:

ndarray

axes

List of axis names giving order of axes in file; options are ‘frame’, ‘row’, ‘col’, ‘channel’

Type:

list

channels

List of names given to each channel (e.g.: ‘dapi’)

Type:

list

name

Optional unique identifier for this image

Type:

str or None

_shape

Cached shape of the image, to avoid reading it from disk multiple times

Type:

tuple or None

__init__(file: str, transform: ImageTransform, axes: list | None, channels: list, name: str | None)
Parameters:

  • file (str) – Path to image file

  • transform (ndarray) – ImageTransform relating (row, col) image pixel coordinates to (x, y) spot coordinates.

  • axes (list) – List of axis names giving order of axes in file; options are ‘frame’, ‘row’, ‘col’, ‘channel’

  • channels (list) – List of names given to each channel (e.g.: ‘dapi’)

  • name (str or None) – Optional unique identifier for this image

classmethod load(image_file, xyscale, channel, name=None)

Read a StereoSeq image file and return an ImageFile object

Parameters:

  • image_file (str) – Path to image file

  • xyscale (float) – um/pixel scale factor used to create the transform matrix

  • channel (str) – Name of channel which this image represents

  • name (str or None, optional) – Optional unique identifier for this image

Return type:

StereoSeqImageFile

get_sub_data(frames: tuple, rows: tuple, cols: tuple, channel: str | None = None)

Get image data for a subregion (defined by frames, rows, and cols, NOT by spot coordinates)

Parameters:

  • frames (None) – not used for stereoseq image files since they are 2d

  • rows (tuple) – first row is inclusive, last_row is exclusive

  • cols (tuple) – first col is inclusive, last_col is exclusive

  • channel (str or None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

XeniumImageFile

class sis.image.XeniumImageFile(file: str, transform: ImageTransform, axes: list | None, channels: list, name: str | None, pyramid_level: int = 0, cache_image: bool = True)

Bases: ImageFile

Represents a single image stored on disk, carrying metadata about:

  • The file containing image data

  • The transform that maps from pixel coordinates to spot table coordinates

  • Which axes are which

  • What is represented by each channel

Image data are lazy-loaded so that we can handle subregions without loading the entire image

file

Path to image file

Type:

str

transform

ImageTransform relating (row, col) image pixel coordinates to (x, y) spot coordinates.

Type:

ndarray

axes

List of axis names giving order of axes in file; options are ‘frame’, ‘row’, ‘col’, ‘channel’

Type:

list or None

channels

List of names given to each channel (e.g.: ‘dapi’)

Type:

list

name

Optional unique identifier for this image

Type:

str or None

pyramid_level

Xenium images are stored as OMEs which support image pyramids. This is the level of the pyramid to load. This is not currently utilized anywhere, but included for potential future use.

Type:

int

_shape

Cached shape of the image, to avoid reading it from disk multiple times

Type:

tuple or None

whole_image_array

Cached array of the whole image data, to avoid reading it from disk multiple times

Type:

np.ndarray or None

cache_image

Xenium images are large and not memory mapped and thus we may want to keep them in memory or not. The trade off is speed vs memory.

Type:

bool

__init__(file: str, transform: ImageTransform, axes: list | None, channels: list, name: str | None, pyramid_level: int = 0, cache_image: bool = True)
Parameters:

  • file (str) – Path to image file

  • transform (ndarray) – ImageTransform relating (row, col) image pixel coordinates to (x, y) spot coordinates.

  • axes (list or None) – List of axis names giving order of axes in file; options are ‘frame’, ‘row’, ‘col’, ‘channel’

  • channels (list) – List of names given to each channel (e.g.: ‘dapi’)

  • name (str or None) – Optional unique identifier for this image

  • pyramid_level (int, optional) – Xenium images are stored as OMEs which support image pyramids. This is the level of the pyramid to load. This is not currently utilized anywhere, but included for potential future use.

  • cache_image (bool, optional) – Xenium images are large and not memory mapped and thus we may want to keep them in memory or not. The trade off is speed vs memory.

classmethod load(xenium_image_file, pyramid_level=None, cache_image=True, name=None)

Read standard Xenium image mosaic tiff file, returning list of XeniumImageFiles

Parameters:

  • xenium_image_file (str) – Path to image file

  • pyramid_level (int, optional) – Xenium images are stored as OMEs which support image pyramids. This is the level of the pyramid to load. This is not currently utilized anywhere, but included for potential future use.

  • cache_image (bool, optional) – Xenium images are large and not memory mapped and thus we may want to keep them in memory or not. The trade off is speed vs memory.

  • name (str or None, optional) – Optional unique identifier for this image

Returns:

stacks – List of ImageStacks, one for each stain

Return type:

list

property shape

Return 4D shape (frames, rows, columns, channels)

Return type:

tuple

get_data(pyramid_level=None)

Return array of image data.

Parameters:

pyramid_level (int or None, optional) – Xenium images can have multiple resolutions stored in an image pyramid. This parameter specifies which level of the pyramid to load.

Returns:

Image data at specified pyramid level

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_sub_data(frames: tuple, rows: tuple, cols: tuple, pyramid_level: int | None = None, channel: None = None)

Get image data for a subregion (defined by frames, rows, and cols, NOT by spot coordinates)

Parameters:

  • frames (tuple) – first frame is inclusive, last_frame is exclusive

  • rows (tuple) – first row is inclusive, last_row is exclusive

  • cols (tuple) – first col is inclusive, last_col is exclusive

  • pyramid_level (int|None, optional) – Xenium images can have multiple resolutions stored in an image pyramid. This parameter specifies which level of the pyramid to load.

  • channel (None) – This is not used for xenium data as we only get DAPI

Returns:

Subregion of image data

Return type:

np.ndarray

ImageTransform

class sis.image.ImageTransform(matrix)

Bases: object

Transfomation mapping between (x, y) spot coordinates and (row, col) image pixels

matrix

2x3 affine transformation matrix mapping from spots to pixels

Type:

np.ndarray

_inverse

Cached inverse of the transformation matrix

Type:

np.ndarray or None

__init__(matrix)
Parameters:

matrix (np.ndarray) – 2x3 affine transformation matrix mapping from spots to pixels

map_to_pixels(points)

Map (x, y) positions to image pixels (row, col).

Parameters:

points (np.ndarray) – Points to map. Must be of shape (N, 2)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

property inverse_matrix

Returns the inverse of the transformation matrix

Return type:

np.ndarray

map_from_pixels(pixels)

Map (row, col) image pixels to positions (x, y).

Parameters:

pixels (np.ndarray) – Pixels to map. Must be of shape (N, 2)

Return type:

np.ndarray

translated(offset)

Return a new transform that is translated by offset (where offset is expressed in pixels)

Parameters:

offset (np.ndarray) – Offset to translate by. Must be of shape (2,)

Returns:

New transform that is translated by offset

Return type:

ImageTransform

ImageStack

class sis.image.ImageStack(images, name=None)

Bases: ImageBase

A stack of Image z-planes Assumes images are all the same shape and evenly spaced along the z axis.

images

List of Image objects

Type:

list

name

Optional unique identifier for this image

Type:

str or None

__init__(images, name=None)
Parameters:

  • images (list) – List of Image objects

  • name (str or None, optional) – Optional unique identifier for this image

classmethod load_merscope_stacks(path)

Read standard merscope image mosaic format, returning multiple image stacks We read merscope into ImageStacks because z-planes are stored across different files.

Parameters:

path (str) – Path to directory containing image files

Returns:

stacks – List of ImageStacks, one for each stain

Return type:

list

get_sub_data(frames: tuple, rows: tuple, cols: tuple, channel: str | None = None)

Get image data for a subregion (defined by frames, rows, and cols, NOT by spot coordinates)

Parameters:

  • frames (tuple) – first frame is inclusive, last_frame is exclusive

  • rows (tuple) – first row is inclusive, last_row is exclusive

  • cols (tuple) – first col is inclusive, last_col is exclusive

  • channel (str or None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

Returns:

3D array of image data (frames, rows, columns)

Return type:

np.ndarray

ImageView

class sis.image.ImageView(image, frames=None, rows=None, cols=None, channels=None)

Bases: ImageBase

Represents a subset of data from an Image (a rectangular subregion or subset of channels) Tracking the view of the image along with the image allows us to serve up subregions accurately when loading images from disk (since we can’t just store the subimaged data array in memory)

image

Image to get data from

Type:

ImageBase

view_frames

Frames to include in the view

Type:

tuple

view_rows

Rows to include in the view

Type:

tuple

view_cols

Columns to include in the view

Type:

tuple

view_channels

List of channels to include in the view. If None, all channels are included.

Type:

list or None

transform

Transformation mapping from pixel coordinates to spot coordinates, adjusted for the view

Type:

ImageTransform

__init__(image, frames=None, rows=None, cols=None, channels=None)
Parameters:

  • image (ImageBase) – Image to get data from

  • frames (tuple or None, optional) – Frames to include in the view. If None, all frames are included. (first_frame is inclusive, last_frame is exclusive)

  • rows (tuple or None, optional) – Rows to include in the view. If None, all rows are included. (first_row is inclusive, last_row is exclusive)

  • cols (tuple or None, optional) – Columns to include in the view. If None, all columns are included. (first_col is inclusive, last_col is exclusive)

  • channels (list or None, optional) – List of channels to include in the view. If None, all channels are included.

property name

Return optional unique identifier for image

Returns:

Name of the image, or None if not specified

Return type:

str

property shape

Return 4D shape (frames, rows, columns, channels) of the view as a tuple

Return type:

tuple

property channels

channels is equal to the number of channels in the underlying image unless specified

Returns:

List of channel names

Return type:

list[str]

get_data(channel=None)

Return array of image data.

Parameters:

channel (str or None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

Returns:

Subregion of image data

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_sub_data(frames, rows, cols, channel=None)

Return a view of this image limited to the given frames, rows, and cols

Parameters:

  • frames (tuple) – first_frame is inclusive, last_frame is exclusive

  • rows (tuple) – first_row is inclusive, last_row is exclusive

  • cols (tuple) – first_col is inclusive, last_col is exclusive

  • channel (str or None, optional) – Name of channel to return data from

Returns:

Subregion of image data

Return type:

np.ndarray
